author: Staff Reporter
text:
The 13{+t}{+h}All India Conference of Central Health Employees (CHEF) held in Jipmer opposed the Seventh Pay Commission Report and demanded to bring amendments to the report. Secretary General Ramkisan said that all the 1100 categories present in health sector including nurses, pharmacists, and laboratory technicians have to be included in the report.

Gazette notification

“We have studied this report but nobody knows about the 1100 categories present in health sector. At least the Pay Commission has not given any name of the categories. The Commission is snatching now what we were getting. Soon this will be in the gazette notification. We expect that there will be no amendment to this,” he said.

Mr. Ramkisan added that the medical fraternity have to go to the streets in protest against this report and to get their rights. “We have placed 26 demands before that Central Labour Commission,” he mentioned.

Jipmer Director S.C. Parija inaugurated the two-meeting on Saturday.

Jipmer Hospital Employees Union also demanded that the recruitment rules should be amended to fill the vacancies.

Need to change recruitment rules

Jipmer Hospital Employees Union general secretary K. Srikanth had said that the recruitment rules were framed in 1970s and needs to be changed in accordance with the present situation.

He added that they would also discuss the Seventh Pay Commission Report during the two-day meet and the cadre restructuring.

All India Central Council of Trade Unions (AICCTU) national vice president S. Balasubramanian said that a need-based minimum wage should be fixed and it would come up to Rs 26,000.

There are no plan framed to address the increase backlogs and the ways to fill the vacancies, he added.
title: Meet criticises 7th Pay Panel report
